posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9518587
I'd make this top 10
1. Castlevania: Aria of Sorrow—must play for everyone. If you pick just 1 game, make it this one.
2. Rhythm Tengoku—best rhythm game I've played. Play if you like quirky games like Wario Ware and rhythm games.
3. Advance Wars—personally not a fan, but those who liked it spent hundreds of hours in it. Very addictive strategy game.
4. WarioWare—quirky and addictive, one of the more original games for GBA. If you've never tried it, do. If you did, still fun to see where it all started from.
5. Metroid Fusion—it's 2D Metroid, enough said. It's great despite some say it's not Super Metroid.
6. Mother 3—not a perfect RPG, but one many people want to play now. Play if you like Earthbound or want an RPG with plot.
7. Wario Land 4—some praise this is as pinnacle of GBA or even best platformer ever, others will write it off as good but ultimately weaker than the GBC ones. Regardless, well worth a try.
8. Mario & Luigi—actually very good RPG, only brought down by bing bang wahoo style and kinda whatever graphics.
9. Kirbies in general—always fun and worth a play. Play if you like Kirby, don't play if you're sick of platformers.
10. Mega Man Zero 3 & 4—decent games, but got pretty overrated recently as some "official canon classics". I beat them all, they're fun and good but not really masterpieces. Play if you like Mega Man X series and / or have played the other 9 games already.
Not on the list:
SNES ports, especially Mario ports—kind of obsolete in current day and age, maybe save for SMW as you can collect dragon coins in it, but that's it.
Pokemons—you either love them or hate them. If you love them, you probably know which ones to play anyway, and may prefer remakes.
Zelda: Minish Cap—it's more Zelda. Play it or skip it, it's alright if you want more ALTTP but thats about it.
Treasure games—no comment.
Mega Man Battle Network—one of those monster / card collect series that just goes on and on.

posts.com:
>Wario Land 4
Considered by many to be the pinnacle of the series (I prefer WL3), due to it's tight streamlining of controls, every level having more unique level design, and easy replayability due to it's short length.

>Metroid Fusion
>Metroid Zero Mission
2D Metroid created by the WL4 team. Fusion is a bit of a black sheep due to it's heavy narrative focus and linearity and Zero Mission is a remake of Metroid 1 but overall both games are still very good.

>Kirby & The Amazing Mirror
If you want Metroid Kirby. I love it though reading the in-game map will be frustrating, it's only real downside

>Game & Watch Gallery 4
If you want to replay old G&W classics but with Mario characters.

>Fire Emblem
>Fire Emblem The Sacred Stones
Still in my opinion the better of the Fire Emblems compared to the later entries. Also obviously the first two games released in the west. Good for a beginner's entry into strategy RPGs

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I have made several retro Windows PCs.

You want period accurate-ish. Slow is good, there are a ton of games that are speed sensitive and it's much easier to get things working and compatible with a good 90s motherboard chipset than "the highest end." That said you can use more modern parts when it makes sense and it's nice to replace hard dicks with SD cards or SSDs.

My fav setups that I've put together are probably
1) a 440bx motherboard with a 1ghz Pentium 3, a voodoo 3, and an ISA OPL3 soundcard
2) a super socket 7 with a K6-III, an nvidia FX5500 PCI, and an ISA OPL3 soundcard connected to an MT-32 & SC-88
3) a socket A mobo with an Athlon XP 2600+, an nvidia FX5700 Ultra, and an Yamaha XG YMF754-R PCI connected to a Yamaha MU90

They all run Win98 and I use them for different eras & kinds of games.

There are a ton of great options though, I also really like the late 2000s era thin-clients I've set up to use Windows & DOS, and shout out to vintage Macs -- a Power Mac G3 is a lot of fun.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You really just need to look at Castlevania 64's contemporaries to see where everything went wrong.

>Super Mario 64
>Ocarina of Time
>Final Fantasy 7
>Metal Gear Solid
>F-Zero X
>Star Fox 64

In a generation where virtually every 2D series worth their salt was making a successful transition to 3D, Castlevania fucked up massively. Even Legacy of Darkness couldn't fix it. People love to go on about its atmosphere these days, but back then, the game looked, played, and sounded like shit compared to everything around it. Worse, CV64 was one of the WORST games in the series at the time, released after Symphony of the Night showed what a modern Castlevania could look like in 2D. 64 failed on every meaningful level to deliver that same quality in 3D.

I hate that people like this game now. I really do.

It's a pretty good game hampered by a truly nothing story. When the world opens up and you can do almost anything you want, that's mechanically interesting, but I don't feel motivated by the plot, characters, or world building. It's kind of the opposite of Mega Man Legends, which has only okay gameplay, but everything around it is so immersive and charming.

Complaints about the controls are invalid, they just require learning and that makes it feel like a proper mech game. Again, the issue is plot-related: I wish they incorporated it better into the story, with Vanilla having more trouble at the beginning but gradually improving.

Finally, there are rather deep dating mechanics, but no h-scenes or anything close, so what's the point.

If emulating, take note of known issues and fixes. They've been unsolved for over a decade so they're probably not going anywhere:
https://wiki.pcsx2.net/Steambot_Chronicles#Known_Issues

posts.com:
>>9531560
>what version should I play and on what system? which has the best looking font? should I play it on an lcd for the sharpest most crisp fonts, or were the fonts designed to be best displayed on a crt?
These questions are kind of beside the point. Infocom games were all implemented using a virtual machine (sort of like the Java virtual machine) called Z-machine, with a bytecode called Z-code. Infocom made all of their text adventures using Z-code, and then had an interpreter for each system they released it on. Every "port" of Zork will have the same Z-code file.
There's no real reason to use the original Z-code interpreters from Infocom, as the format has been completely reverse-engineered. There are modern interpreters for Z-code for whatever platform you want - Windows, Mac, Linux, Android.
Also get the PDFs of the original documentation. There's a manual, a "history" explaining the background of the game, and a few other things.

>>9526446
Animation, sound, art design, level design/variety are all top-notch. Boss design is great and plenty of enemy variety. Primary and secondary weapons are well-balanced and there is a trade-off between more firepower vs. higher rank.

What I really love though is the slower, more deliberate approach to the game. I think that's what a lot of people struggle with, this is a game where you are really meant to proceed with caution and really take advantage of the fact that the game doesn't autoscroll. Every time you play, you get a bit more efficiency, a bit better method to approach a section, and can better parse the vast amount of information that is thrown at you at once. And then when you start to get really good, you can do speed strats (unfortunately there is no scoring incentive, but still fun). It's definitely a game that grows on you.

The game itself is not really that slow, especially when you know what you're doing. If you mean slowdown, yeah it is pretty bad (just like the Metal Slug games), but you can remove it through emulation and the game is massively improved.

The rank system is kinda fucked though; the game is actually easier if you don't pick up all the powerups. You need to make the decision between rushing past sections or going slow and thorough. When you learn the game, you can do sections very quickly and pointblanking shreds bosses.

Just like with the Slug games, turbo + removing slowdown makes the game so much better. With turbo you can also pointblank the last boss and it dies way faster (he also has less health with lower rank from not picking up as many powerups). I'm not sure what other problems you are having with the last level, it's just all about routing and figuring out how best to approach each section consistently (like any good shmup/run-n-gun)

I do think that In the Hunt is much more of a game that grows on you, but once you "get" it, it's honestly just as good as the best of the Slug games, but in a different way with a totally different feel. In terms of 1CC or 1LC, In the Hunt is probably actually easier than even like Slug 1, it's just a more rough learning curve.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
SHVC units are the SNES equivalent of the first Famicoms from '83 that got recalled. Avoid that shit garbage; the chips in those self-destruct. The single PPU models (RGB, 1-Chip, and SNES Jr) have some technical changes as well as a different and sharper video signal with the GPM-02 being the only stable, reliable version of the original twin chip PPU.

Yes unfortunately with the early SNESes they rushed out an incomplete beta model and relied on customers to do their field testing for them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9533202
It's some primitive form of Dolby Surround that uses math to encode additional audio channels in the two sterel outputs. If you have a compatible surround system, it'll do some math and basically decode the stereo in to some additional channels. I think it's just some phase shifting and shit like that, no modulation or anything complicated.

Question is why you would need it. I do remember figuring out that A Link to the Past had some nice stereo panning when I first used headphones while playing it, but I don't see much use for additional sound channels in 2D games.

With some extensive Googling and searching, I found a couple of references to it on TVTropes (unsourced, and who knows when they were added), a brief thread about it on R*ddit from earlier this year, and then some scant few mentions of it in the archives of /vr/ and /v/ dating back the past decade or so.
If it's actually true, potentially the one source is actually in Japanese and it's something that's only been wandering around the western world by word of mouth, and either it was never translated, or the translation of it fell off the web at some point.

What we have to back it is 1, that the claim of the idea has been passed around for a long time (never challenged and never sourced), but of slightly stronger substance, 2, there's some interviews with the devs where they do actually mention that Namco made them change a number of things about the game to tone it down, such as making the zombies less realistic and human looking, making the blood green, etc.
There's no mention about the concept of the player character, but that wouldn't have to mean that it wasn't something which changed during development, regardless of it was something changed in the last minute as often told of, or if it was something which was proposed but nixed early on. The player initially being proposed as an evil killer looking to murder a poor girl, then being changed into a hero trying to save his girl would be going from a darker to a lighter tone, and it would make the fact that the player looks like a famous slasher horror killer less inexplicable.

You can clean mold off VHS tapes. Open top case of VCR. Fast forward the tape. As its running, lightly press Qtip dipped in rubbing alcohol against the capstan so the tape runs across it. Cleans all the mold off. I've done it several times and saved some rare tapes this way.

posts.com:
- CRTs are no longer produced because they have inferior picture quality versus LCDs
- CRTs emit dangerous levels of X-rays or other forms of radiation
- CRTs always have easily-visible flicker
- CRTs always cause eyestrain
- CRTs always make a high-pitched squealing noise
- CRTs contain lethal amounts of electricity, even when unplugged
- CRTs need calibration more than two to three times a year
- Overall CRT black levels are not superior to LCDs because ambient light ruins CRT black levels
- Analog CRTs have more processing time than digital LCDs due to poor RAMDAC performance
- Afterimages caused by phosphor decay are extremely annoying and are a significant downside of CRTs
- Sending an improper mode (resolution or refresh rate) to a CRT can cause permanent damage
- CRTs cannot have touchscreens
- 4:3 is so bad that nobody should use a non-widescreen CRT
- The Sony GDM-FW900 is the only CRT worth owning
- Curved CRTs have objectively inferior picture quality versus flat CRTs with otherwise equal specifications
- CRTs should not be used because they are heavier and deeper than LCDs
- CRTs have severe reflections because they do not have matte coats
- CRTs can be permanently damaged by nearby magnets
- You will not have sex in 2023
- Analog signals limit a CRT's resolutions and refresh rates and negatively effect picture quality
- Heavy metals are used in CRT glass to reduce radiation

>>9513353
rgb's only necessary if you think it is. composite's ok if you're ok with it. rgb makes the video signal cleaner so you don't get certain video artifacts that you do with composite. some people actually prefer composite because of those artifacts. the only time rgb might be "necessary" is if the console or whatever only outputs rgb (i can't think of any examples of this, maybe there's a computer like this) or if there's some detail you can't make out on composite, which might be discernible on rgb but it could just be that the screen itself can't resolve the detail (because of dot pitch or convergence or what have you).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
OP bothered me that much I'm going to briefly summarise the flow and design of each level in Einhander as a counter argument.

>Stage 1
>Metropolis background, moving billboards, neon signs can be destroyed, battle amongst skyscrapers, branching path leads to former city underground with unexploded warhead, final section takes place along highway

>Stage 2
>Wasteland stage, involves following an armoured train, train has multiple moving parts, some of which are destructible, action shifts from foreground to background, final section takes place in cave

>Stage 3
>Large vertical shaft inside industrial facility as play field whilst game still functions on horizontal field, broken up by Boss battle, returns to a vertical section with a lowering destructible ceiling that deploys enemies, stage continues horizontally, final section is in room that rotates according to Boss' weight

>Stage 4
>Stage introduces water with reflective surfaces and skimming effects, marine enemies appear, perspective changes to display Boss swimming underwater, proceeds to branching routes with moving elevators, final section includes destructible background and Boss battle takes place on surface after breaching

>Stage 5
>Spaceport stage with indoor and outdoor sections after the previous two stages taking place fully indoors, Boss is shown lurking behind background before battle, destructible background elements, final section takes place on climbing runway

>Stage 6
>Takes place entirely in the sky in which the objective is to destroy the rocket that has been launched within the time limit, Boss battle then takes place above the atmosphere, hidden Boss included

>Stage 7
>Space stage with turbulent movement to simulate effects of combat in space, assisted by lighting, enemies explode in different directions accordingly, Final Boss incorporates this with additional whirling camera

Not to mention the way each stage has its own atmosphere and various unique features.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
the breadbin C64 has unreliable, hot-running chips because MOS used an ancient and not very efficient 5-6 micrometer process from the 70s. the VIC-II in particular was quite power-guzzling as it's a very busy chip that has to perform all graphics functions, bus mastering, and RAM refresh, and its internal speed is 8Mhz. after three years of bungled attempts they switched to a modernized lower power 3 micrometer process which is what the C64C chips use.

so combination of some outdated tech and MOS not having especially good engineers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The VIC-II devotes 70% of its total die space to sprites because the aim was to overpower Atari with advanced sprite capability. However it also made the chip pretty inefficient and hot running due to the large amount of silicon needed for that. As for SID, Bob Yannes originally wanted six sound channels but didn't have time to implement that. So basically they wanted cutting edge audiovisuals but were constrained by cost limitations and not having the most modern manufacturing tech.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9533723
The PLA was a common failure point in many breadbins. It was the first HMOS chip they did and they had lots of problems with that. PLAs had such a high failure rate at first that Commodore shipped machines with known faulty chips to meet shipping quotas, hoping customers would return the non-working C64 and it would be swapped for a board with a known good PLA.

There are several good ports. My personal favorite way to play is the M2 3D one on the 3ds. They did a phenomenal job and even fish in a given school are at different depths. I have played it emulated many times though with no issue.

I do recommend a guide if you feel stuck, there are two quests near the beginning where you rescue lost dolphins and those give you very useful abilities for the rest of the game.

Finally though, if you find yourself very stuck or the game is too hard, or you just want to play it more casually, all versions including the GBA port have the debug code which is quite robust.

You can yourself invulnerable if you want, level select or teleport to any area of the current zone. Almost more fun though is you can change the music tempo which given Ecco's incredible soundtrack makes for some really cool variations you can do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9532972
Good luck with it, I'm glad to help! It's one of my favorite games of all time, but I understand well why it's always been a little niche. My suggestion if you try again is just take it slow for a while and learn how the game flows. The second level has an octopus that is there to help teach you. You'll feel low on air and like you should be rushing, but the octopus will slap you back of you do. In Ecco, rushing is what usually kills you. Your air is always depleting and you will think you're going to drown if you don't, but success relies on keeping calm under pressure and being accurate. Many people say it's crazy hard, but really outside of the Asterite fight and the Vortex queen at the end, it's really not that difficult ot just takes a kind of mentality that most games don't require as much.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9529034
Dolphin is a great example of an interface that actually needs to incorporate gamepad controls. There's no reason I need to use a mouse to select a game to play. There's no reason there's hotkeys like the screenshot or pause emulation button that have to be on keyboard instead of gamepad. Some gamepads even have mouse control built in, meaning if Dolphin had a proper console interface in the console emulation software, you'd only need a gamepad to have full control over it.

Retroarch does it correctly, as it is actually control agnostic insofar as an emulator can be. Since you're supposed to play these games on a gamepad, it supports gamepad controls itself. If I'm sitting on the couch, playing on my TV, I should not need to deal with this stuff.

posts.sub: Games you discovered far too late
posts.com: Has there been a game you started playing too late in life to truly enjoy? For example I played Unreal 99 for the first time a few months ago and it was amazing. But the whole time I played against BOTs all I could think about was how much more I would of enjoyed playing it if it was 20 years ago as a kid and I still had my friends to play with

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I was there, I can tell you.
It was fucking amazing, probably the most adrenaline-filled FPS multiplayer gaming I have ever experienced in my life. There were so many fucking servers, and you would often join a server with open slots only to be told it was already full. Didn't matter, there were always more servers with people on them. There were different classes of players out there. The noobs that didn't even attempt the singleplayer campaign who were target practice. The somewhat experienced players who've been playing for a while and don't know the maps by heart yet but aren't likely to be doing stupid things like standing still. The vets with good aim and who knew the maps who usually were around the top of the scoreboard.
Then there were the really good players who only used the melee weapon and the teleporter. You could usually spot the last group dueling each other in the skies of outdoor maps like it was a fucking DBZ fight, each trying to telefrag or melee the other without getting nailed themselves. If you ever got a kill on these guys, it was pure luck. 95% of the time you wouldn't even know one was there, you would just suddenly explode as one teleported into you.
It's sad all that remains today is one 24/7 vanilla Facing Worlds server where people just snipe 24/7, and a handful of heavily modded servers that aren't even really UT1999 anymore. I'm sorry you missed it anon, it was one of the best.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9530328

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9530328
The one I missed out on was Delta Force: Joint Operations. I managed to play the demo and had great fun playing it online, but then I ended up working somewhere out in the middle of nowhere with no internet for about two years. By the time I got back online and got a copy of the full game, barely anyone was playing anymore. No more stock maps, all funky looking custom maps that are gimmicky and a pain to play. No vehicles on any of the custom maps either. A few years later, and the only people still playing are no-lifers who demand you join a squad and RP as a solder and show up to regular practices and blah blah blah or you can't even play on their server.
Really bummed about that to this day, because the demo was so much fun to play on the one map you could play online. Hopping on the minigun of a helicopter while someone flew it around and another guy hooked on the bench sniping at anyone trying to shoot us down, or racing around the ocean against three other guys in Zodiacs, just had a gameplay like Battlefield 1942 without being as janky as BF1942. The airduels in helicopters was always fun.

>>9530361
I'm sorry you missed it too. UT circa 2000-2001 was the golden age.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: Experiencing Majora's Mask as a Kid
posts.com:
The first time I played The Legend of Zelda: Majora's Mask it was newish. I was doing a sleepover at a friend's house.

I still feel nauseous just thinking about it. From the very first scene, Link and Epona isolated and weary in the eerie forest, Epona being taken, and pretty much everything to do with the Skull Kid. Being transformed into a shrub. The schizodemonic mask salesman and his scene's odd Battlefield Earth (2000) fuckery. Three days huh?

I step out into The oddly claustrophobic town with guards at every exit and holy moley the MOON wtf. Three days! Around this time my head is hurting sweetly. How do I escape this and see the new Hyrule Field? Ho, this gang of kids will help after a game of hide & se- YOU FUCKERS DO YOU NOT SEE THE MOON. They scatter, I search, the clock ticks, my hands begin to sweat. If I were really Link there'd be some casualties by now that Nintendo did not intend.

I find the last kid. I go down their clubhouse and meet a new dancing scarecrow. It is speaking gibberish even though I do not think that's what the developers intend. I hate the scarecrow, so much, and at this point I'm experiencing some nausea.

I move on and talk to old man at the observatory who, as everyone else I've met, lacks a proper sense of urgency. I look into his telescope and I see... that the clock is still ticking. Even while I peer through the scope the clock ticks. I don't know why I expected some moment of reprieve but I did, and it wasn't there. My mouth is dry and my bowels feel all twisted up. I run outside the observatory and see that I am trapped in a yard. I double check hurriedly as the clock ticks.

I break. I drop the controller, excuse myself, and go to vomit in my friend's bathroom- crying, snotting out, heaving, head splitting. Eventually I face my friend's mom to ask to use the phone to go home... She says NO! She tells me to go to bed. SHE WAKES ME UP AT 3AM TO HELP HER AND HER SON DELIVER NEWSPAPERS.

8/10 never playing again

Decompiling is a pain, and usually, you will need to sort out a lot of things by yourself.
Even if decompilers now can separate code from data (which is helped in consoles starting at PS1 gen because some sort of memory formatting was common) you will likely end up with assembly with variable and functions name meaning nothing.
Well, at least, I tried it for the game boy, and so it was.
I don't see why PS1 would be different (except maybe if they let the debug symbols on the final CD? That's not unheard of, but quite rare).

Anyways, good luck, and enjoy your project!
It you can post your advancements here, that would be really great.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9520325
The Jetsons Invasion of the Planet Pirates comes to mind.
As a licensed game developed by Taito for the SNES, they re-used the game engine and level designs for another licensed game in Japan; Youkai Buster: Ruka no Daibouken.

The game is mostly the same, but the key differences aside from the change in characters and visuals, is a different intro cutscene, the introduction of bonus levels after each action level's boss fight, a whole new final boss, and the inclusion of additional cheat codes whilst the game is paused. The game is however two levels shorter, not all levels were converted from the original game, but some mini-game segments were put in their place.

Whichever version you play though, it is a genuinely good game, nothing amazing, but worth a play.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9531151
First, take a crash course in electronics circuits.
Then, build a transiver from 5V to 3.3V.
I think the best way to do it would be to use an ESP32 with WiFi.
Then, code some kind of API (check if extension is present, init, get access point list, connect to one, send a request, receive an answer, etc.
Then, code the software (and if you ant it to be useful, think of it as a project using a lib. Like, don't do some URL check or whatever in the game code.)
Lastly, enjoy!
I would start super simple with a game that just check if the extension is plugged.
An other on that does that and list the networks and their strength.
Lastly, one that goes and fetch a text file somewhere on the internet.

As for the hardware, I don't know what buses the NES have exposed. Maybe the same as cartridges? If so, you are midly fucked. You expansion may present as a RAM page, where you write at some addresses, and it gives you answers at other addresses?

Software-level stuff isn't a barrier for me since I've done plenty of ASM in the past. The motivation was more about adding network features to existing games. One crazy idea that has been in my head for the past few weeks was a SMB3 NES/SNES rom hack I wanted to call "Doomship Raider", where you could take over enemy airships by playing them, crudely build your own, fly to locations, and seize other players' ships by invading them with your own. It's already enough that I'm writing a brand new level editor for SMB3, so it really is just a time-investing interest that could crop up if I've got time I don't want to waste on something else.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9532426
>Are there any NES games that make use of the "illegal opcodes" I hear exist in the 6502?
"Games using unofficial opcodes

The use of unofficial opcodes is rare in NES games. It appears to occur mostly in late or unlicensed titles:

Beauty and the Beast (E) (1994) uses $80 (a 2-byte NOP).[2]
Disney's Aladdin (E) (December 1994) uses $07 (SLO). This is Virgin's port of the Game Boy game, itself a port of the Genesis game, not any of the pirate originals.
Dynowarz: Destruction of Spondylus (April 1990) uses 1-byte NOPs $DA and $FA on the first level when your dino throws his fist.
F-117A Stealth Fighter uses $89 (a 2-byte NOP).
Gaau Hok Gwong Cheung (Ch) uses $8B (XAA immediate) as a 2-byte NOP. The game malfunctions after selecting Left from the main menu if that instruction is not emulated.
Infiltrator uses $89 (a 2-byte NOP).
Puzznic (all regions) (US release November 1990) uses $89 (a 2-byte NOP).
Super Cars (U) (February 1991) uses $B3 (LAX).

Homebrew games

The MUSE music engine, used in Driar and STREEMERZ: Super Strength Emergency Squad Zeta, uses $8F (SAX), $B3 (LAX), and $CB (AXS).[3]
Attribute Zone uses $0B (ANC), $2F (RLA), $4B (ALR), $A7 (LAX), $B3 (LAX), $CB (AXS), $D3 (DCP) and $DB (DCP).
The port of Zork to the Famicom uses a few unofficial opcodes."
From: https://www.nesdev.org/wiki/CPU_unofficial_opcodes

In most video games for the Olympics, football/soccer, and team sports in general, were usually left out, with the main exception I can think of being... the Mario & Sonic franchise. 2020 was probably the best year in that regard, both Mario & Sonic at Tokyo 2020 and the official Tokyo 2020 video game feature football/soccer, and both have better turfs and lighting than eFootball still, which is sort of funny.

When it comes to video games that are 100% made with Olympic football/soccer in mind I can only think of Olympic Soccer 1996 and Winning Eleven 2000, with the latter actually being incredible to me.

I wish that we'd get these stand alone adaptations again, or maybe that the official Paris 2024 video game actually gives the sport more care and adds the official players and nations, anything but a bare bones DLC for EA Sports FC or eFootball that'll just be lost in time eventually, I want to be able to go back to a tournament like I can go back to any FIFA World Cup before 2018, when it became a DLC.

I've been giving FIFA more changes recently, especially on Genesis and PS1, but they're never my cup of tea, either they're just not fun to play, downright frustrate me (FIFA19 I'm looking at you) or are just so inferior to what Konami had to offer at around the same time, sometimes even inferior to other developers, since back then it wasn't a duopoly. AoW seems to be written in Delphi, judging from the .dpl files (they're just dlls btw).
The UI uses the Visual Component Library that is based on Win32 API but adds a lot of custom controls. Looks like it was one of the easiest way to build good looking GUIs in Windows at the time.

As for VNs from that time, maybe they used the Windows API with custom engines in C or C++ or even languages like Hot Soup Processor.
Then engines like KiriKiri and Nscripter got popular.

>>9525986
Most Rockstar games are these sequences of arbitrary, barely playable one-off tasks that are ridiculous enough to be entertaining on paper but not too ridiculous for the setting. That's not a dumb way to design your realistic sandbox when missions have good flow and presentation that naturally weave you into these tasks, but that's not what Bully does or even can do. The world doesn't make up for the bad gameplay but is completely dead and eventless until you get to the point where your task or minigame happens, which is either frustrating or way too easy and not worth exercising more than your bare minimum for because you know it's just another cheap one-off thing. They clearly didn't respect the setting of their own game and knew just throwing the GTA principle at a boarding school would be enough for the media and journalists to make it sell. Not even asking for a proper morality system or good NPC AI, but, contrary to what the title promises, you can't even live out your inner bully in this game or do anything too evil

If there was a PC source port you can combine the best of the PlayStation and Saturn versions to make an ultimate hybrid.
From Sony:
>the extra jump button (srsly why wasn't the Saturn controller better utilized?)
>better audio and FMV quality overall (maybe hand-pick the few things that are supposedly better on Saturn, like Aqua Man's stage theme)
From Sega:
>extra enemy placements only help an already easy game (MAYBE just get rid of the first two enemies being Mets or at least move them later in the level since that seems remarkably lazy, like "oh boy we gotta have em it's a Mega Man game," plus it frankly spoils the mood of the first enemy being a surprise turret supposed to be set in a covert base)
>instead of Duo's stage reusing the opening stage theme, have it use Saturn Tengu Man's stage theme - it's short enough and fits SO much better there (MAYBE keep the flash when you enter, but ONLY have it sound ONCE as an atmospheric effect for the first screen transition inside, otherwise it badly drowns the music)
>graphical alterations: use the additional hologram background effect in Astro Man's battle transitions, and the orange Robot Master name font because pink is overused; DON'T use the water effect due to potentially hindering spike-section gameplay, or the pixel-different HUD icon due to being pointless.
>keep Cutman and Woodman as bonus boss fights with the following changes: 1) remove the badly-written pre-battle dialog, they serve no purpose and it ruins the second "oh snap" half of the music you normally only hear at Bass, 2) allow the player to refight them if the stage is selected again like any other miniboss, 3) move Woodman's location so he's now optional just like Cutman, &4) MAYBE a better reward instead of moved bolts.
>include Bonus Mode, but hide it behind Game Information and the code from Saturn credits, and upgrade quality of illustrations reused in Legacy Collection museum.
Plus things expected of a PC port like language select.

>>9532438
Anyone ever notice that Cut Man and Wood Man were always part of the same shot in the opening animation? It's Wood Man, Centaur Man, Spark Man, Skull Man, Gyro Man, Cut Man, and Freeze Man. These are different from the RobotMasters shown in earlier in the FMV since those were dramatized flashbacks of the original games - this is a new scene of robots from each game ganging up on Mega Man. So my theory is that Cut Man and Wood Man from the Saturn version are a remnant of a much bigger plan for the PlayStation version. I really think you were originally supposed to revisit each level ala Mega Man 3, which is why a lot of Bolts require a second visit. Recall that Mega Man 8 was supposed to be the 10-anniversary game. There was probably a plan to make that series celebration more evident, but things fell through.

>>9518520
Which version you want to play is mostly a matter of graphics. Some think the early release is more atmospheric, others prefer the redrawn versions. See pic related.

Either way, make sure to play a version that has the original still screen gameplay instead of freeroam. The still screens were designed around making things you were supposed to find easily visible, so if you play a freeroam version without having played the original first, it's very easy to miss things that were never meant to be hard to find.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9518548
It was extremely significant at the time and is an important point on the timeline of how videogames progressed, so if you're interested in that which the people here who aren't just literally autistic and refuse to play anything they haven't played 1000 times before presumably are it's worth playing just for that reason. It's also a 3D art style that existed in the 90s where fidelity was starting to get to where things are recognizable and nice looking but still very artificial, it gives art like this a dreamlike quality and, at least to me, gives a powerful feeling of what the tech world was like generally back then, I can't look at myst without remembering stuff like the transition from dos to windows, the optimism, just that time period in general and I think that would come through even for someone without memories of that time. It's not a terribly exciting game, but it wasn't back then either. Play it to experience what we considered top of the line art and technology back then, don't expect it to be some kind of thrill lol. It's an adventure game.

>extremely significant at the time
Yeah, but it was mainly because CD-ROM craze. It sold in absurd numbers, but was it really that influential, besides spawning a ton of imitators? First person adventure games were nothing new, and neither was environmental storytelling. Without that, Myst only has graphics. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9518646
It literally pioneered pre-rendered graphics and environmental storytelling. You're going to say no its some other retarded obscure game, but yes, it did. It was a popular game that proved that both concepts could be relevant and it is extremely historically important. The way that Myst told its story, along with the manner the world presents things is a massive precursor to many games that would be released after it.

Also, even till this day, when the art is at its best (e.g. Sirrus's rooms) it is beautifully detailed. FYI, I played Myst for the first time this year, so no, I'm not nostalgiaing over it. The game has great design for its time and is a foray not only into environmental storytelling, but storytelling period in games. Just compare the stories of games that came before Myst and you'll see what I mean.

>>9518520
Myst and Myst Masterpiece Edition are identical in content, but Masterpiece has better audio and color depth compared to the original release. Play Masterpiece Edition if you want less dithering. The only version released after Masterpiece Ed that I can recommend is the first remake, RealMyst (2000), Not to be confused with RealMyst: Masterpiece Edition (2014), or Myst (2020). Realmyst has a lot of minor visual inconsistencies with the original game, but I felt that it preserved the visual tone in realtime 3D better than the sort of tacky 2014 version. I haven't played 2020 Myst, but it doesn't look great, and is and even bigger departure than any of the other remakes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Myst
>original release
>pre-rendered images with video sequences
>lots of dithering on everything due to limited palette
Myst Masterpiece Edition
>graphical update from 8-bit color to 24-bit color so far less dithering used
>a dithered blue pillow turning purple since that was the color dithered to make blue, and the white pages inside the two books in the library have been tinted to match their covers, otherwise just improved graphics all around since used the same source material used to make the first game only without dithering down to 8-bit color
>added hint system for already easiest graphical adventure
realMyst
>3D remake of Myst, all graphics needed to be redrawn because of this
>added a grave on Myst island to match plot of the prequel books
>added another age accessible after beating the game that has another puzzle or two that is pretty meh overall, but hints at Riven
>dynamic weather/time system
>can be laggy even on modern machines due to engine being ported away from Glide to DirectX at the last minute and barely any optimization
realMyst Masterpiece Edition
>overhaul of realMyst with different engine and redone graphics
>a lot of shadows, details, and added stuff like the trees in that one age having a lot more leaves all the way up the trunk
>can look overly shiny and flashy, but still runs smoother than realMyst on modern PCs
>bloom and depth of field effects, trees move a bit in the wind
There's pretty much zero reason to play the original over Masterpiece Edition. If you aren't doing a 3D version, then that's the one to play. For 3D, you pick the one that you prefer the looks of. I prefer realMyst, others prefer the ME.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9526646
It's revisionist history. Myst came out in 1993, but it wasn't the #1 seller until later on. I remember reading a deep history on Myst that talked about how it didn't start selling really well until 95-96, and was even outselling Riven after it released. And by 95-96, most people had at least a 4x CD-ROM drive. CD's as a medium took off because of music CD's. They had far superior sound than cassette tapes, didn't wear out if you stored them properly, and you could skip to the song you wanted instead of fast-forwarding to get to where you wanted. Computers were already headed that way since 1.44MB floppy disks were turning game/program installs into 10-20 disk ordeals. That's what drove the adoption of the CD format. Sims and graphical adventures going with recorded speech instead of just text. Play the floppy disk version of Kings Quest 5 or Return to Zork, then the CD-ROM version. The pressure to get a CD drive was there before Myst released.

>>9529697
Fair enough; I'll admit that the point I'm making is one that I usually make when JRPG fags criticize me for playing shorter, punchier action games (that don't waste my precious free time with literal chores like grinding and farming), and claiming that their JRPGs are the better option because "muh hours of gameplay per dollar". At least SRPGs have more going for them than just grind for hours and mash confirm until win. But I'm still adamant about quality over quantity when it comes to hours of gameplay in a game. Give me a choice between a 20 hour game that's fun and engaging the entire time, or a 100 hour game with 40 hours of fun and engaging gameplay and 60 hours of tedious chores, and both games are the same price, I'll take the 20 hour game every time.
